Interesting work! I have seen sulfuric acid mentioned in older books for sealing ground glass joints, never tried it myself. Perhaps it was used more before modern high temperature greases. Dont know if it is a real risk, but I would probably put a safety flask between the trap and the receiver flask in case  suckback  should occur...

You know you can get PTFE sleeves for ground glass joints, right? They slip over the inner cone of the "male" end of the joint. If you use these, you can jam the joints together as tightly as you like, and they will not seize up. This also means that you don't have to use anything else to lubricate the joints. If you can't find the sleeves, then you can use ordinary plumbers PTFE tape instead, which you can just wrap around the "male" cone. Use at least two overlapping layers of tape - it's tedious to do and tends to disintegrate a bit when you twist the joints apart again, but you can always re-do it since the tape is cheap. Neither of these are of much use if you need to pull a high vacuum on the system, because the seal will not be 100% perfect. But for any other purpose, it's good enough.

Also, please for safety sake put some old rubber or plastic tube on the curved metal prongs of your clamps - bare metal clamped against glass is an uncomfortable sight. The large difference in thermal expansion between metal and glass means that either the clamp can come loose, or worse - it cracks the glass joint. Some tubing covering the prongs provides a cushioning effect and increases the friction between the clamp and the glass - so it won't crack the glass if it's a bit too tight, and won't slip out if it's a bit too loose.

Something to consider as well: Not all sulfuric acid based drain cleaners have the same additives in them and they do behave differently.  I've tried both methods with a few different brands and while distillation works for all of them a few brands do NOT work well with H2O2.  In fact there are 3 I have encountered which outright refuse to clear up with H2O2.  They just turn into a black, tar filled mess that can only be cleaned up through distillation.  Based on this I too only use distillation and I just HATE doing it.  But this is the only source I have available.  On a side note I have a friend that works for a large hardware type store.  It's kind of a depot of sorts if you know what I mean.  She used to get me my drain opener by the case but they no longer carry it and she told me that I should expect to see this happen at most other retailers in Canada.  So basically stock up while you can.  This stuff appears to be going the route of HNO3 too.

1:20 - "So why can't we get a 100% sulphuric acid?" - why, but of course "yes, we can!" (well, at least in US under Obama...) - but not through destillation of less concentrated acid, that's right. Still, we can "easilly" obtain a 100%, or even 120% (and still more!) concentrated H2SO4. Whichis called "oleum [vitrioli]". lit. "corrosive oil" (AFAIK).
This "oleum" is NOT to be confused with "oleum dulci vitrioli", and it is 100% H2SO4 with an additional SO3 dissolved in it. And this is how we get "100% and above" concentrated H2SO4. (BTW, "oleum dulci vitrioli" is ethyl ether, as it is often obtained by distilling mixture of dry ethanol and concentrated H2SO4.)
Auntie Wiki provides more detailed explanation: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oleum
Also, a smooth piece of glass is not an ideal "boiling stone", as it has, well... smooth surface - just as smooth as the flask itself (maybe with exception for that grinded cone at it's opening). A piece of crushed ceramic would work better, and you don't really need "a whole bunch of them" - two or three pieces are more than enough. All you need is lov...erm, I mean, "all you need here is SOME starting points" for boiling, in order to avoid superheating the distilled liquid.

I find you have to treat with H2O2 and then distill. I usually do two treatments with H202 followed by distillation. Each treatment is about 10ml of 30% in about 200ml of concentrated acid. The first treatment is allowed to react for a while and then heated until it stops bubbling. Some cleaners will go very dark during this step. In these cases, I definitely recommend a second H2O2 treatment. When I do a second treatment, the reaction is allowed to proceed for days or until the bread-like smell gives way to pungent vapors that smells like HCL.
The final distilled product may eventually develop a pungent smell. If this happens, just add about 1ml 30% H2O2 to it and let it react until the smell is entirely gone, then heat until the reaction is terminated.
NOTE: Keep in mind that, after H2O2 treatment, the sulfuric acid contains a lot of dissolved gas. Unless you heat it long enough to degas it when you terminate the reaction, then be careful when heating it for distillation. If you heat it too quickly, it might begin to develop gas too fast and pump itself up into the condenser. You don't want that, trust me.

8:20 Your crazy burst of hard bumping is caused by the broken glassware, which does not have the same properties and effects of standard ceramic boiling chips. Your assumption at 7:00 that bubbling off the glass was and indicator that the pieces would make suitable substitute boiling chips was in error because those bubbles were resulting from a combined effect of added energy into the system (in the form of kinetic agitation when the were dropped into the flask) and increased surface area for the solution to come into contact with and you had yet to more the set up outdoors and increase the heat to start the actual boiling process. The edges and surfaces of the glass pieces are all smooth, the ceramic edges and surfaces of boiling chips are rough, and it is this difference that caused the bumping. During the boiling process the gases of what is being boiled off (in this case the O2, CO2, and gaseous H2O) would normally catch in the tiny grooves and pockets created by the grainy texture of the ceramic surfaces where they would build then release in miniscule bubbles and this is what slows the speed of how fast the gases rise to the surface of the liquid they are escaping and hence how the boiling chips help prevent an over-boil situation. The smooth nature of the glass edges does not allow for the formation of tiny slow-forming bubbles along its surfaces. The pattern of repeated burst with the bumping was the gasses becoming trapped and collecting under the glass pieces until enough was built up to the point of being able lift the glass and allow for an escape to the surface, and it starts all over when the glass pieces fall back down and begin trapping the gasses again. Also, there are additional hazards trying to deal with knife-sharp glass edges when trying to transfer contents or when cleaning afterwards. Hopefully this information will be useful for everyone to consider before attempting to use broken glassware as make-shift boiling chips.

I know I'm late to the party but I wanted to point out that there are many, many different kinds of 'sand' that regular people use not knowing that there is SiO2 or 'silica' sand which is what NileRed is talking about then there is Carbonaceous sand which is CaCO3 (shell material from critters in oceans and stuff). If you plan to use 'sand' as a nucleation material for, whatever really, please be sure you are using the appropriate 'sand'. Try to find pure quartz sand that isn't super weathered or rounded. You want it to be course since it provides enough surface area for nucleation to occur as opposed to heavily rounded, smooth sand. And absolutely stay away from anything carbonaceous unless it is called for.

The real reason you cannot boil off the last 2% H2O is because of the self-dissociation equilibrium given as H2SO4 <--> SO3 + H2O.

Anyone here who is trying to concentrate sulfuric acid with a wide mouth, open container like a beaker even outdoors and especially (apparently) when it is hot, humid and with only a slight air current: if you carry the process far enough the sulfuric acid “smoke” will become very thick. Because it is also very hot it will convect up to about 10-15 feet but will cool and start coming back down as a fog. This fog may only be barely visible, especially at night and you may even think “well, if I stay 20-30 ft away and hold my breath when I get closer, I’ll be fine”. And you probably will. But here’s the thing. Holding your breath only closes off your lungs from the outside air. Your nasal cavity, back of your throat, etc are still exposed to the concentrated fog up close. You will probably experience the following for several hours afterward (do not be alarmed, you don’t have pulmonary edema): sensation of needing to cough, raspy voice, lots of mucous/drainage, sensation of irritation up to burning in the back of the throat.

However, if you have trouble breathing or start exhibiting signs of oxygen deprivation (pale to bluish skin, especially the lips, nails, etc), fatigue, confusion, feeling extremely light-headed. Get help immediately. Fresh air first of course. But I find such a scenario highly unlikely outdoors.

If you do this indoors you MUST cut off the heat as soon as you see the first hint of white smoke that is not water vapor.

Just a thought but the amount of sand you used looks way too much. You just want to provide a few nucleation points for the boiling, so just a thin layer at the bottom will suffice. After all, you want the fluid to be a uniform temperature. Using so much sand will effectively compartmentalize the bit at the bottom near the mantle and evaporate (boil) it locally. The thick sand is acting as both an insulator and a fluid barrier, relatively speaking.

Regarding "I haven't really come up with a foolproof way to determine that it's 98% sulfuric acid." The boiling point vs. concentration curve for sulfuric acid solutions is fairly steep. Given that you're already boiling it in the first process, you should be able to get a good idea of concentration if you had a thermometer that could measure up to ~350C. Then you only have to measure one variable, rather than needing to accurately measure both density and temperature.

Alternatively, even if your thermometer isn't very accurate, it should be clear that it's 98% when the temperature stops rising. May be able to read that with an IR thermometer.

When I distilled drain cleaner, at no point did the light distortions stop, even close to the end of the run when I was sure that azeotropic acid was being distilled. I think this is because as you said, the density of sulphuric acid varies a lot depending on temperature. Since I used an air condenser, the acid is still at ~50˚C when it drips into the flask. So as the temperature of the sulphuric acid inside the receiver cools, new hot acid will be at a different temperature and so will still cause light distortions. Did you experience this problem?
